FacilityName: Pilgrim's Pride - Athens AL Processing Plant
DeregistrationReasonOtherText: This facility has been shut down and the ammonia removed.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the Pilgrim?s Pride Athens, AL Poultry Processing Plant.  The reason for submitting this corrected RMP is to update the site Accident History.  This facility had one ammonia refrigeration system with an inventory capacity above the EPA threshold reporting quantity of 10,000 pounds at the time of the Accident.  The total quantity of anhydrous ammonia in the system has not changed significantly since the most recent RMP plan was submitted in June 2004, and no significant additional controls have been added to the process.

Management at the Pilgrim?s Pride Athens, AL Processing Plant recognizes its responsibility in protecting employees, equipment, property, and the environment.  The safety and health of all personnel and the neighboring community are very important.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel at the facility.

Pilgrim's Pride Corporation is committed to the safety of its employees, the communities surrounding its plants, and the environment.  This commitment includes both human health and environmental protection.  Safety is ensured through careful preventive measures and emergency planning.  The intent of our release prevention policy is to minimize all potential risks that could possibly lead to an accidental ammonia release.  This program focuses primarily on the safe operation and the mechanical integrity of the refrigeration process equipment.  The Emergency Response Plan focuses on reducing the potential impact of an accidental release.  This is done by coordinating emergency actions of the plant HAZMAT Team with the Athens Fire Department.  This is achieved by ensuring that employees are trained on the proper response to an emergency situation and by getting the members of the Fire Department acquainted with the facility.

Because anhydrous ammonia is listed by both the US Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the US Environmental

Protection Agency (EPA) as a hazardous chemical, our accidental release prevention policy is designed to comply with the Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations of these two agencies.  These regulations are designed to prevent the accidental release of ammonia and minimize negative consequences in the event that a release should occur.  Our emergency response policy is designed to comply with all government emergency response regulations.

An offsite consequence analysis was performed for the Athens, AL facility site, including consideration of ammonia release scenarios as ?worst case release? and ?alternative release scenario?. We do have several active mitigation systems to minimize any effect incidents like these would have.  We also incorporate several management systems to decrease the likelihood of this incident occurring.

Pilgrims Pride Corporation?s accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

?  Hands-on and classroom training of the refrigeration partners.
.  Preventative maintenance programs.
.  Operating procedures, written with the participation of the refrigeration partners.
?  Performance of process hazard analyses of the entire system including equipment and piping.
?  Design and implementation of an auditing and inspection program.
?  Procedure for handling all changes to the system.
?  Pre-Startup review procedures for significant system modifications.
?  Up-to-date process safety information.
?  Procedures for investigating release incidents or near-misses.
?  Hot-work permits for work on or near the ammonia process.
?  Line Break procedures.

This program was developed with the participation of Pilgrim?s Pride Corporation refrigeration partners.  They were also instrumental in developing the Process Safety Information.  Anhydrous ammonia pipes and valves are labeled and equipment information has been compiled.  The Company follows the International Institute of Ammonia Refri

geration (IIAR) guidelines for safe operations and preventative maintenance of the refrigeration equipment.  In addition, the facility has procedures in place for notifying contractors and their employees of the hazards pertaining to the system, as required under the regulations.  Chemical-specific exposure prevention steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) and air purifying respirators for the refrigeration partners, and awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of anhydrous ammonia.  We also give our refrigeration partners HAZWOPER training on an annual basis.

In accordance with the PSM and RMP regulations, the Company performs periodical audits and hazard reviews to enhance continued safe performance.  Several recommended actions to improve safety were identified during these audits and reviews and are tracked regularly for timely completion as required.

An emergency response program has been implemented at the facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia spills and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  This program has been coordinated with the Athens Fire Department.

The emergency response program consists of the following elements:
Organization Plan and Responsibilities.
Communications Procedures.
Detailed Action Plans.
First Aid Procedures.
Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures.
Evacuation Plans.
Description of Outside Assistance Available.
Site Re-Entry Procedures.
Training Programs and Drills.
